    Leadership Isn‚Äôt Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It‚Äôs Just Good Process

    By Someone Who‚Äôs Not Here to Sell You Positivity Kool-Aid

    When people talk about ‚Äúleadership‚Äù in tech (and especially in IT project work), the conversation often splits into two camps.

    There‚Äôs the Chipper Brigade:

    • Always smiling
    • Always upbeat
    • Always talking about ‚Äúsynergy‚Äù and ‚Äútransformational journeys‚Äù
    • Probably has a spreadsheet color-coded by the phases of the moon

    And then there‚Äôs people like me:

    • Direct, measured
    • Focused on the outcome, not the parade
    • Calmly skeptical because, well, we‚Äôve seen things
    • More ‚Äúlet‚Äôs execute well‚Äù than ‚Äúlet‚Äôs all feel amazing while burning down scope‚Äù

    Here‚Äôs the truth: both approaches can work. But one of them tends to survive real-world IT projects with fewer therapy bills.

    Leadership, Without the Pom-Poms

    Thanks to a slightly unusual combination of strengths (Gallup‚Äôs Deliberative, Responsibility, Relator, Analytical, Learner, and a healthy dash of Command), and a neurodivergent brain wired for pattern detection, I approach leadership a little differently:

    • I don‚Äôt pretend problems aren‚Äôt there. Leadership isn‚Äôt about ignoring risk. It‚Äôs about managing it deliberately, responsibly, with eyes wide open.

    • I don‚Äôt need everyone to ‚Äúfeel amazing‚Äù all the time. I need everyone to know what their job is, have the support to do it, and be able to escalate real issues without fear of being told to ‚Äújust stay positive.‚Äù

    • I‚Äôm not obsessed with being the loudest voice in the room. I‚Äôm obsessed with the signal-to-noise ratio. Good leadership is making sure communication cuts through cleanly, not making everyone louder.

    In short, I‚Äôm not the glass-half-full leader, nor the glass-half-empty one. I‚Äôm the ‚Äúwho‚Äôs in charge of topping up the glass?‚Äù leader. It‚Äôs the difference between optimism and operational reality.

    Most IT Projects Are Simple, If You Manage the Process

    Here‚Äôs the dirty little secret of most IT projects, especially in cloud and security:

    • The technology is not the hard part. Vendors (and engineers) like to act like it is because it makes them feel important, but if you can read and click a mouse, most modern platforms are straightforward (after the 15th acronym, anyway).

    • Managing change is the hard part. People. Expectations. Timelines. The process around change. Communication. Handling resistance without letting it fester into sabotage. That‚Äôs where projects live or die.

    • Communication is not the same as cheerleading. Communication is making sure people know what‚Äôs happening, when, why it matters to them, and what to expect next. It‚Äôs setting clear expectations, not inflating them with empty positivity.

    So when I ‚Äúlead,‚Äù it‚Äôs not with relentless smiles or rah-rah speeches. It‚Äôs with deliberate planning, direct communication, and ruthless clarity on what matters. That‚Äôs what builds trust. That‚Äôs what drives outcomes. That‚Äôs what gets projects done.

    The Velvet Hammer Approach

    I‚Äôve been described as a ‚Äúvelvet hammer‚Äù direct but not cruel, firm but fair, outcomes-focused without trampling people.

    That‚Äôs leadership too. It just looks less like a TED talk and more like an architect quietly pointing out where the foundation needs to be reinforced before the house collapses.

    And honestly?

    In IT (and especially in security), I‚Äôd rather be the architect than the hype man.
